title: Assignment01
text:
You can find some examples of generative art through the link below.
https://aiartists.org/generative-art-design
2.Run Fall.R(on class GitHub under R)
a.Give your owncolors(e.g. Spring).
I picked red1 color.
b.Export the file and post on your GitHub website.

# Title Fall color
# Credit: https://fronkonstin.com

# Install packages

install.packages("gsubfn", repos = "http://cran.us.r-project.org")

Installing package into 'C:/Users/sksk/AppData/Local/R/win-library/4.2'
(as 'lib' is unspecified)


package 'gsubfn' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked

The downloaded binary packages are in
    C:\Users\sksk\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpqEkpuw\downloaded_packages

install.packages("tidyverse", repos ="http://cran.us.r-project.org")

Installing package into 'C:/Users/sksk/AppData/Local/R/win-library/4.2'
(as 'lib' is unspecified)


package 'tidyverse' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked

The downloaded binary packages are in
    C:\Users\sksk\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpqEkpuw\downloaded_packages

library(gsubfn)

Loading required package: proto

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching packages
───────────────────────────────────────
tidyverse 1.3.2 ──


✔ ggplot2 3.3.6      ✔ purrr   0.3.4 
✔ tibble  3.1.8      ✔ dplyr   1.0.10
✔ tidyr   1.2.1      ✔ stringr 1.4.1 
✔ readr   2.1.2      ✔ forcats 0.5.2 
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

# Define elements in plant art
# Each image corresponds to a different axiom, rules, angle and depth

# Leaf of Fall

axiom="X"
rules=list("X"="F-[[X]+X]+F[+FX]-X", "F"="FF")
angle=22.5
depth=6


for (i in 1:depth) axiom=gsubfn(".", rules, axiom)

actions=str_extract_all(axiom, "\\d*\\+|\\d*\\-|F|L|R|\\[|\\]|\\|") %>% unlist

status=data.frame(x=numeric(0), y=numeric(0), alfa=numeric(0))
points=data.frame(x1 = 0, y1 = 0, x2 = NA, y2 = NA, alfa=90, depth=1)


# Generating data
# Note: may take a minute or two

for (action in actions)
{
  if (action=="F")
  {
    x=points[1, "x1"]+cos(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    y=points[1, "y1"]+sin(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    points[1,"x2"]=x
    points[1,"y2"]=y
    data.frame(x1 = x, y1 = y, x2 = NA, y2 = NA,
               alfa=points[1, "alfa"],
               depth=points[1,"depth"]) %>% rbind(points)->points
  }
  if (action %in% c("+", "-")){
    alfa=points[1, "alfa"]
    points[1, "alfa"]=eval(parse(text=paste0("alfa",action, angle)))
  }
  if(action=="["){
    data.frame(x=points[1, "x1"], y=points[1, "y1"], alfa=points[1, "alfa"]) %>%
      rbind(status) -> status
    points[1, "depth"]=points[1, "depth"]+1
  }

  if(action=="]"){
    depth=points[1, "depth"]
    points[-1,]->points
    data.frame(x1=status[1, "x"], y1=status[1, "y"], x2=NA, y2=NA,
               alfa=status[1, "alfa"],
               depth=depth-1) %>%
      rbind(points) -> points
    status[-1,]->status
  }
}

ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),
               lineend = "round",
               color="red1", # Set your own Fall color?
               data=na.omit(points)) +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +
  theme_void() # No grid nor axes




3.Write a critique on a chart in published work (book/article/news website)
The material presented below are excerpts from Yonhap News, one of the Korean media outlets.

This material shows the status of breakthrough infections by vaccine type and age in Korea. At first glance, it is easy to recognize as a percentage, so it looks like a lot of breakthrough infections are appearing. However, if you look closely, what the numbers mean is the number of breakthrough infections per 100,000 people. So, if you calculate it as a percentage, you can see that it is a fairly low number. The author may not have expressed the figures as percentages, as this data is quite small when set in percentage terms. However, as a result, this material can cause people to misunderstand.

title: Assignment02
text:
a. Be sure to run line by line and note the changes


b. Pay attention to the comments and address the question if there is one
Question 1. plot(pressure, pch=16) # Can you change pch?
Yes, we can change the pch. If we change pch, the shape of the points on the graph changes. For example, if we change pch to 1, points appear as a hollow circle like the first one on the right in the figure below. Also, changing pch to 2, 3, 4 changes the shape of the points on the graph as follows:

Question 2. points(x, y1, pch=16, cex=3) # Try different cex value?
Changing the cex value changes the size of the point. That is, the larger the number, the larger the size of the point. For example, if you look below, the first picture is when the cex value of the black point is set to 1, and the second picture is when the cex value of the black point is set to 5.
cex=1

cex=5

Question 3. axis(1, at=seq(0, 16, 4)) # What is the first number standing for?
This code creates an axis. The first number 1 in code “axis(1, at=seq(0, 16, 4))” means the lower horizontal axis among the axes. Thus, running the code “axis(1, at=seq(0, 16, 4))” produces the lower horizontal axis as below:

c. Plotting functions (note: exercise using the happy planet data set http://happyplanetindex.org)

rm(list=ls())                          # Clear environment


library(readxl)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(ggplot2)
library(gridBase)
library(grid)

HPIdata<-read_excel("happy-planet-index2019.xlsx")


par(mfrow=c(3, 2))

# Setting label orientation, margins c(bottom, left, top, right) & text size
par(las=1, mar=c(4, 4, 2, 4), cex=.7) 
plot.new()
plot.window(range(HPIdata$HPI), c(0, 16))
lines(HPIdata$HPI, HPIdata$Ladder_of_life_Wellbeing)
lines(HPIdata$HPI, HPIdata$Ecological_Footprint)
points(HPIdata$HPI, HPIdata$Ladder_of_life_Wellbeing, pch=16, cex=2) # Try different cex value?
points(HPIdata$HPI, HPIdata$Ecological_Footprint, pch=21, bg="white", cex=2)  # Different background color
par(col="gray50", fg="gray50", col.axis="gray50")
axis(1, at=seq(20, 65, 5)) # What is the first number standing for?
axis(2, at=seq(0, 10, 2))
axis(4, at=seq(0, 16, 2))
box(bty="u")
mtext("HPI", side=1, line=2, cex=0.8)
mtext("Ladder of life (Wellbeing)", side=2, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
mtext("Ecological_Footprint", side=4, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
text(4, 5, "Bird 131")
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), col="black", fg="black", col.axis="black")

# Histogram

par(mar=c(4.5, 4.1, 3.1, 0))
hist(HPIdata$Ladder_of_life_Wellbeing, breaks=seq(0, 10), ylim=c(0, 0.5), 
     col="gray80", freq=FALSE)
lines(density(HPIdata$Ladder_of_life_Wellbeing), lwd=2)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))


# Boxplot
par(mar=c(3, 4.1, 2, 0))

boxplot(Ladder_of_life_Wellbeing ~ Continent, data = HPIdata,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:8 - 0.2,
        col="white",
        xlab="",
        ylab="Ladder_of_life_Wellbeing", ylim=c(0,10))

mtext("Continent", side=1, line=2.5, cex=0.8)

par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))  

# Persp
x <- seq(-10, 10, length= 80)
y <- x
f <- function(x,y) { r <- sqrt(x^2+y^2)+7; 10 * tan(r)/r }
z <- outer(x, y, f)
z[is.na(z)] <- 1
# 0.5 to include z axis label
par(mar=c(0, 0.5, 0, 0), lwd=0.5)
persp(x, y, z, theta = 15, phi = 20, 
      expand = 0.5)

par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), lwd=1)

# Piechart
par(mar=c(0, 2, 1, 2), xpd=FALSE, cex=0.5)
pie.sales <- c(0.20, 0.10, 0.30, 0.10, 0.25, 0.05)
names(pie.sales) <- c("Milk", "Water",
                      "Juice", "Smoothie", "Coffee", "Other")
pie(pie.sales, col = rainbow(6))

# Barplot

HPI1 <- data.frame(HPIdata$Continent, HPIdata$HPI)


HPI1 <- transform(HPI1, HPI_grade = ifelse(HPIdata$HPI < 30, "5", ifelse(HPIdata$HPI >= 30 & HPIdata$HPI < 40, "4", 
ifelse(HPIdata$HPI >= 40 & HPIdata$HPI < 50, "3", ifelse(HPIdata$HPI >= 50 & HPIdata$HPI < 60, "2", "1")))))




plot.new()              
vps <- baseViewports()
pushViewport(vps$figure) 
vp1 <-plotViewport(c(0.1,0.1,0,0))

p <- ggplot(HPI1, aes(HPIdata.Continent, fill = HPI_grade)) +
  geom_bar(position="stack")+ theme(legend.title=element_text(size=10), legend.text=element_text(size=10), legend.key.height= unit(0.1, 'cm'))
print(p,vp = vp1)
print(p,vp = vp1)

title: Assignment04
text:
# Data Visualization
# Assignment 4-1

# Set Column Names
df <- data.frame(x = c("Texas", "Florida", "NewYork",
     "California"), width = c(25, 50, 75, 100), height = c(100,
     75, 50, 25))

df$w <- cumsum(df$width)
df$wm <- df$w - df$width
df$wt <- with(df, wm + (w - wm)/2)

library(ggplot2)
p <- ggplot(df, aes(ymin = 0))
p1 <- p + geom_rect(aes(xmin = wm, xmax = w,
     ymax = height, fill = x))

p2 <- p1 + geom_text(aes(x = wt, y = height *
     0.5, label = x))

p2 + ggtitle("Carbon Emission and Gas Price by State") + xlab("Gas Price") + ylab("Carbon Emission")




The figure above shows the relationship between carbon emissions and gas prices by state. California has the highest gas price and the least carbon emission. On the other hand, Texas has the least gas price while the highest carbon emission. The figure illustrates that the higher the gas price, the lower the carbon emissions.

title: Assignment04
text:

library(ggplot2)

# Calucating Mean
mean(carbon$PerCapitaEmission)

[1] 20.29298



# Creating Dummy Variable
carbon$PerCapitaEmission_dummy <- ifelse(carbon$PerCapitaEmission>=20.20489, 1, 0)

# Creating Ordinal Variable
carbon$CarbonIntensity_ordinal <- cut2(carbon$CarbonIntensity, m=10)

# 
table(carbon$PerCapitaEmission_dummy, carbon$CarbonIntensity_ordinal)

   
    [ 71.2, 197) [196.6, 270) [269.6, 342) [342.4, 500) [500.1,1035]
  0           11           10           10            3            0
  1            0            0            0            7           10



carbon_df <- data.frame(carbon)


p <- ggplot(carbon_df,aes(CarbonIntensity_ordinal,PerCapitaEmission,fill=as.factor(Division)),size=5)+geom_bar(position="dodge",stat="identity")+facet_wrap(~CarbonIntensity_ordinad,nrow=4)
